title: Starbucks.com is reachable via ip address thus possible to link any doamin to Starbucks.

profile.name: Starbucks
profile.about: Inspiring and nurturing the human spirit -- one person, one cup, one neighborhood at a time.

vulnerability_information:
It is possible for anybody to buy a domain name containing negative terms and point it to someone's website in order to damage their reputation. For instance someone could buy the domain child-pornography.com and point it to the address 107.162.135.91 which is the address behind starbucks.com

To illustrate this, I added the entry 107.162.135.91 o my /etc/hosts file and tested. Here is what I obtained:Refer screenshot 1
personally found this user experience terrible as someone could think that starbucks are in favour of child pornography (i just demonstrated it on my domain i.e hackingig.com)

I tested with other websites and experienced other behaviors that I would categorize as follows:

1 - Useful 404 page (happens with www.teavana.com) one of your domain:
For me the worst way of handling this as the image of the targeted website is directly associated with the offending domain. The more useful the 404 page, the bigger the impression that the targeted website would be willing to help with child pornography.

2 - Redirection (happens with microsoft.com):
For instance when accessing child-pornography.com you get redirected to www.microsoft.com. It isn't as bad as above as the offending domain name never appears alongside the targeted website's content, but still bad in my opinion as it gives the impression the targeted website bought the offending domain and redirected it to their website to get more traffic.

3 - Server error (happens with lemonde.fr):
You get an error from the webserver which page doesn't contain any content that can be associated with the targeted website (e.g. default Apache 404 page, completely blank page). I believe that is good as the identify of the targeted website isn't revealed.

Above are the various behaviors I experienced, but I also thought about a fourth way of dealing with this which is described below.

4 - Disclaimer page (haven't found any website implementing that technique):

Display a message such as :

"You ended here because someone bought and linked the  child-pornography.com domain to our website. We do not own this domain and do not associate ourselves with it. This request has been logged by our servers and we will raise this issue with the competent authorities to have this domain taken down. If you want to access our website, please click here."
The good thing about this method is that it can be implemented at application layer (good if you don't have control over web server which happens with some hosting solutions), allows you to protect yourself from any liability, and offer the visitor to be redirected to your own website.
vulnerability_information_html:
It is possible for anybody to buy a domain name containing negative terms and point it to someone's website in order to damage their reputation. For instance someone could buy the domain child-pornography.com and point it to the address 107.162.135.91 which is the address behind starbucks.com

To illustrate this, I added the entry 107.162.135.91 o my /etc/hosts file and tested. Here is what I obtained:Refer screenshot 1
personally found this user experience terrible as someone could think that starbucks are in favour of child pornography (i just demonstrated it on my domain i.e hackingig.com)

I tested with other websites and experienced other behaviors that I would categorize as follows:

1 - Useful 404 page (happens with www.teavana.com) one of your domain:
For me the worst way of handling this as the image of the targeted website is directly associated with the offending domain. The more useful the 404 page, the bigger the impression that the targeted website would be willing to help with child pornography.

2 - Redirection (happens with microsoft.com):
For instance when accessing child-pornography.com you get redirected to www.microsoft.com. It isn't as bad as above as the offending domain name never appears alongside the targeted website's content, but still bad in my opinion as it gives the impression the targeted website bought the offending domain and redirected it to their website to get more traffic.

3 - Server error (happens with lemonde.fr):
You get an error from the webserver which page doesn't contain any content that can be associated with the targeted website (e.g. default Apache 404 page, completely blank page). I believe that is good as the identify of the targeted website isn't revealed.

Above are the various behaviors I experienced, but I also thought about a fourth way of dealing with this which is described below.

4 - Disclaimer page (haven't found any website implementing that technique):

Display a message such as :

"You ended here because someone bought and linked the child-pornography.com domain to our website. We do not own this domain and do not associate ourselves with it. This request has been logged by our servers and we will raise this issue with the competent authorities to have this domain taken down. If you want to access our website, please click here."
The good thing about this method is that it can be implemented at application layer (good if you don't have control over web server which happens with some hosting solutions), allows you to protect yourself from any liability, and offer the visitor to be redirected to your own website.

Hi @cj862530 can you state which domain you update the IP with ours? When going to hackingig.com it shows me your blog. Also we are investigating this as well so once we get info if this a valid report, we will update it. :)
Cheers,
@rockyrobot

Hi @cj862530 thank you for the report. I decided to retest this myself and found that this does not bring security issue. You are correct that if I put the A record of my domain to 107.162.135.91, I do get Starbucks page loaded on my website. However the page shown is just a static page. If you were to go to lets say /account/signin/ you will get UT001000: Connection closed error. This will prevent any phishing attempt as well. That being said, this does not bring any security risk, so I am closing this report as Not Applicable.

Thank you for participating in our program. We look forward to more reports from you in future.
@rockyrobot

activities.message:
Though i cannot login  into your website but as you can clearly see in video i am able to navigate to different webpages under my domain, though this directly do not affect the security but somewhere it has to do with the brand value.Starbucks is a very popular brand and it has direct impact on brand.. what if someone purchase a bad domain name and link it to starbucks website.
So you should definitely block accessing website via ip address and if that is not possible to block as if have got many subdomains then you validate that any badrequest is redirected to your main domain. i.e www.starbucks.com.

Still if you think i point is invalid and you are not going to fix it i would request a public disclosure and also  upload this vulnerability on my blog and youtube channel but before that i will wait for your reply.

activities.message:
Hey @cj862530 

are you aware that ```/etc/hosts``` is your local resolver ? This being said, your PC is first looking in this file wether there is an entry for the domain you are requesting. You can imagine the ```/etc/hosts/``` like your local telephone directory which has nothing to do with the DNS root servers (https://www.iana.org/domains/root/servers) which inherit the original IP of starbucks to the domain starbucks.com. If you now change it in your local file you "trick" your own system into making weird things, but only yourself and no one else.

If you need additional information: 

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_Name_System
- http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/hosts.5.html
- http://www.faqs.org/docs/securing/chap9sec95.html

Thank you for your understanding on our decision for this submission. 

If you have additional questions please don't hesitate to ask. 

If you think our decision is wrong on this one, please add additional information so we can re-evaluate. 

best

@rubikcube

see it has been three days since my last reply but i have not received any revert..just to show you that site can be accessed globally.. i have binded starbucks.com to my website i.e. www.hackingig.com and still it is live.You are not understanding the criticallity of this issue. since it is my live website i will be keeping your domain binded to my website for next 24 hours..after that i will be restoring my website and i will be disclosing these report publically on my website,youtube channel and on different hackers group on whats app and also request public disclosure on hackerone.

In future if you get too see starbucks website under bad domain name then it is not my fault i have already made you aware of this issue and given much more time to analyze things also I have shown interest in helping you to get this issue fixed but i am not getting response from your end.

If i don't get revert i will be disclosing it publically on 24-January-2017 12.30 PM EST.

Thanks.

activities.message: Hi @cj862530, you're spot on that we're clearly don't understand how critical this is :) We'd like to work with you here, but that requires you to explain why this is so critical. Would you mind trying to explain the impact to us one more time? It usually works really well when you come up with a good, working proof of concept. This might be something we'd address, but I'd like to wait with triaging this before understanding it. Sorry for the confusion here, we're trying to understand (you're probably right!). Thanks for helping us out!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @cj862530, you're spot on that we're clearly don't understand how critical this is :) We'd like to work with you here, but that requires you to explain why this is so critical. Would you mind trying to explain the impact to us one more time? It usually works really well when you come up with a good, working proof of concept. This might be something we'd address, but I'd like to wait with triaging this before understanding it. Sorry for the confusion here, we're trying to understand (you're probably right!). Thanks for helping us out!

activities.message:
Thanks to god finally you are able to reproduce it.
You know very well that starbucks is a very popular brand and has a very good market reputation.

Now lets try to understand the impact of this attack:
A competitor of starbucks or lets say an attacker will purchase domain like dirtycoffee.com or any vulgur domain name and binds starbucks ip to that domain, and then he viral that link (an attacker can use url shortner like bitly.com to craft it more smartly), saying for coupon code click here so the domain name will be www.xxx.com but under that domain site loaded will be of starbucks. for eg. 
www.xxx.com/coffeehouse
www.xxx.com/menu
www.xxx.com/tea

I mean to say domain name is www.xxx.com but site rendered is completely of that of starbucks.

Even an attacker can post dirty pics on social media saying for more fun click (link will be say www.xyz.com) but the site loaded will be of starbucks. An attacker can perform a mass phishing attack.

so what customers will think, it is a subdomain of starbucks or starbucks is promoting such activities to catch attention of people, so they visit  website and place 

order or whatever be the reason.

Most of the clients do not give their source code to anyone there may be multiple security reasons but one of the reason is that no one can host their site malaciously. Here i am able to bind starbucks site to any domain just by entering ip.

Here my complete point is starbucks should not allow to open there website via just entering the IP, it should either display 404, or best way is to redirect it to their main domain i.e. www.starbucks.com

Business impact:
It can lead to Loss of reputation which is a very big loss to comapny.

To consolidate briefly i would say an attacker can carry out mass phishing attack to spoil to reputation of starbucks by binding site to any bad domain name thus resulting in loss of reputation of company.

As it can directly impact the reputation of company i am saying it critical.

activities.message: @cj862530 Thanks for your elaborate answer, appreciate it! One question that comes to mind when reading the entire thread here, is how this is any different from redirecting a user to a certain domain, e.g. starbucks.com. I understand the technical difference, but in terms of impact, how is this different? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: @cj862530 Thanks for your elaborate answer, appreciate it! One question that comes to mind when reading the entire thread here, is how this is any different from redirecting a user to a certain domain, e.g. starbucks.com. I understand the technical difference, but in terms of impact, how is this different? Thanks!

activities.message:
I didn't got your question clearly but i am considering that your are asking about open redirection.
In redirection a victim is unknowingly redirected to a particular domain for eg.
 http://example.com/example.php?url=http://www.attacker.com so here when user click on the link trusting it is a example.com domian and will land up on same domain but that is not the case after clicking he will be redirected to www.attacker.com, so after loading in url it will display www.attacker.com which will be purely attacker.com and has nothing to do with http://example.com/.

But in our case when user click on xyz.com the domain remains same i.e xyz.com but site which is rendered is of starbucks.com.So the impact is that people will think xyz.com is a subdomain of starbucks.If the domain name is dirty then people will think starbucks is supporting such activities to grab attention of people.A new way of marketing strategy, ultimtely spoiling reputation.

PFA screenshot there the site name is hackingig.com but site rendered is of starbucks.com
I hope this was your doubt which i tried to explain in simple way.

If you still have any queries please feel free to ask.

activities.message: so you should mitigate it by blocking to open to site by ip address, if that is not possible then you should redirect the ip to main domain i.e www.starbucks.com. Also the best way is to move the setup to cloud.
activities.markdown_message: so you should mitigate it by blocking to open to site by ip address, if that is not possible then you should redirect the ip to main domain i.e www.starbucks.com. Also the best way is to move the setup to cloud.

activities.message: Thanks, @cj862530! I believe the fix is rather straightforward here, but unfortunately I'm really failing to see the issue here. This is almost the exact same thing as proxying traffic to starbucks.com from a domain, which would actually be worse to some extend, since that'd allow you to capture user information. I'll check with the team, but I doubt that we'll accept this as a real security vulnerability under our bug bounty program. Thanks for your patience!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks, @cj862530! I believe the fix is rather straightforward here, but unfortunately I'm really failing to see the issue here. This is almost the exact same thing as proxying traffic to starbucks.com from a domain, which would actually be worse to some extend, since that'd allow you to capture user information. I'll check with the team, but I doubt that we'll accept this as a real security vulnerability under our bug bounty program. Thanks for your patience!

activities.message: Hi @cj862530, wanted to thank you again for being so thorough here. I brought this up with the team, but this is not something that we're going to fix now, nor do we believe that this is a security vulnerability. Besides the occasional misconfiguration that actually has a security impact, we're most interested in bugs that actually have (in)direct security implications (such as XSS, CSRF, RCE, SQLI or authentication/authorization bypasses - to name a few). I'm sure you know a lot about security, but try to focus more on bugs that are exploitable (also for the cash bonuses we reward for real security bugs - we love to pay for awesome finds!). Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @cj862530, wanted to thank you again for being so thorough here. I brought this up with the team, but this is not something that we're going to fix now, nor do we believe that this is a security vulnerability. Besides the occasional misconfiguration that actually has a security impact, we're most interested in bugs that actually have (in)direct security implications (such as XSS, CSRF, RCE, SQLI or authentication/authorization bypasses - to name a few). I'm sure you know a lot about security, but try to focus more on bugs that are exploitable (also for the cash bonuses we reward for real security bugs - we love to pay for awesome finds!). Happy hacking!
